TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   Patient had PICC line removed and tip sent for culture.  Spiked fever
   to 102 and received tylenol.  NGT in satisfactory position, got oral
   barium for CT abd/pelvis. Pt with respiratory rate 25-35 overnight.
   Allergies:
   Iodine; Iodine Containing
   Anaphylaxis;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Vancomycin - [**2123-5-13**] 08:47 PM
   Micafungin - [**2123-5-14**] 05:41 AM
   Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn) - [**2123-5-14**] 06:20 AM
   Infusions:
   Other ICU medications:
   Pantoprazole (Protonix) - [**2123-5-13**] 08:47 PM
   Fentanyl - [**2123-5-13**] 11:52 PM
   Other medications:
   Changes to medical and family history:
   Unchanged
   Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below
   Review of systems:
   Unchanged
   Flowsheet Data as of  [**2123-5-14**] 06:37 AM
   Vital signs
   Hemodynamic monitoring
   Fluid balance
                                                                  24 hours
                                                               Since [**25**] AM
   Tmax: 39.3
C (102.8
   Tcurrent: 37.7
C (99.9
   HR: 93 (93 - 119) bpm
   BP: 135/76(89) {96/58(67) - 137/94(104)} mmHg
   RR: 35 (26 - 38) insp/min
   SpO2: 100%
   Heart rhythm: SR (Sinus Rhythm)
             Total In:
                                                                  1,454 mL
                                                                    165 mL

                                                                    275 mL

                                                                    474 mL
                                                                   -820 mL
   Respiratory support
   O2 Delivery Device: Tracheostomy tube
   Ventilator mode: CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow
   Vt (Set): 500 (500 - 500) mL
   RR (Set): 24
   RR (Spontaneous): 0
   PEEP: 5 cmH2O
   FiO2: 40%
   RSBI Deferred: RR >35
   PIP: 22 cmH2O
   Plateau: 23 cmH2O
   Compliance: 38.5 cmH2O/mL
   SpO2: 100%
   ABG: 7.47/32/172/20/1
   Ve: 16.9 L/min
   PaO2 / FiO2: 430
   Physical Examination
   Gen: Intubated, not responsive to verbal stimuli
   HEENT: NCAT, tracheostomy in place
   Pulm: CTAB no rales/rhonchi/wheezes
   CVS: RRR with normal S1 and S2, No m/g/r
   Abd: Multiple drains in place.  T tube draining biliary fluid, other JP
   drains draining green fluid. Midline incision c/d/I with staples in
   place.
   Ext: Trace pitting edema bilateral LE. 2+ pedal pulses.
   Labs / Radiology
   309 K/uL
   9.3 g/dL
   125 mg/dL
   1.4 mg/dL
   20 mEq/L
   4.5 mEq/L
   81 mg/dL
   113 mEq/L
   145 mEq/L
   28.1 %
   11.7 K/uL
        [image002.jpg]
                             [**2123-5-13**]  05:27 PM
                             [**2123-5-14**]  03:26 AM
                             [**2123-5-14**]  03:32 AM
   WBC
   12.8
   11.7
   Hct
   27.6
   28.1
   Plt
   283
   309
   Cr
   1.7
   1.4
   TCO2
   24
   Glucose
   95
   125
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.4/30.8/1.4, ALT / AST:439/462, Alk Phos /
   T Bili:151/11.2, Amylase / Lipase:/21, Differential-Neuts:84.3 %,
   Lymph:12.1 %, Mono:2.4 %, Eos:0.7 %, Lactic Acid:1.5 mmol/L,
   Albumin:2.2 g/dL, LDH:399 IU/L, Ca++:8.1 mg/dL, Mg++:2.3 mg/dL, PO4:4.9
   mg/dL
   CXR:
   Trach Terminating 5.8 cm above carina.  NGT terminating below diaphragm
   with tip off the film. Bibasilar atelectasis.
   CT Torso with PO contrast:
   Abd/pelvis: Complex post-surgical anatomy is difficult to delineate.
   Oral contrast is seen in the stomach and within a bowel loop descending
   anteriorly near the midline, which is presumed to represent the jejunal
   limb anastamosed to the first portion of the duodenum. Additional
   contrast is seen in the third and fourth portions of the duodenum,
   which per the surgical team are not
   contiguous with the first portion of the duodenum. this may reflect
   contrast reflux vs contrast from prior t-tube fluoro studies.
   There is no intraabdominal fluid collection, though there is extensive
   stranding in the region of the duodeunm and pancreatic head, likely
   post-surgical. the left anterior abdominal wall collections are
   essentially resolved, though there is again significant inflammatory
   change that persists. two drains are noted in this region. of note,
   more inferiorly in the abdominal wall there (2:100-104 and 300b:25)
   there is hyperdense material noted. given hx of possible feculant would
   drainage, this may represent extraluminal contrast suggesting fistula
   vs alternatively post-[**Doctor First Name 91**] material
   from component seperation/mesh repair.
   Drains/tubes: Gastrostomy in LUQ laterally. Two subQ drains, on
   entering on left and one entering on right, both coursing through the
   right subQ tissue, superficial to the abdominal wall, at the site of
   prior large fluid collection. T-tube appears to be appropriatly
   positioned, extending from the duodenum to the region of the porta,
   exiting in RUQ.
   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. male s/p multiple surgical interventions at an OSH now being
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concern for infected mesh, infected hematoma,
   and respiratory failure.
   # Fever: Likely abdominal source given Klebsiella, Enterococcus from a
   hematoma at his surgical wound site.  Concern for infected mesh +/-
   hematoma.
   - Trend temp curve, WBC
   - Send blood cultures, urine culture, sputum culture, biliary cx, 3 JPs
   cx
   - f/u culture data from all drain sites
   - Continue GNB coverage with IV Abx, Vanc and Zosyn
   - Micafungin for yeast
   - Surgery team consult (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]; f/u any recommendations
   - ID consult in AM
   - Resite lines (obtain peripherals, pulled PICC)
   - TTE today for ? endocarditis
   .
   # Head Bobbing: ? seizure activity.  Started yesterday per daughter. [**Name (NI) **]
   history of seizures in the past, though decreased rhythmic activity
   over night.
   - EEG
   - head CT
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: possibly due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C
   infection
   - continue to trend
   .
   # ARF: Reached peak of 1.9 from baseline of 1.0. Likely prerenal given
   elevated sodium
   - patient received fluid bolus with 1L NS and had creatinine drop to
   1.4 and sodium to 145.
   - continue IVF boluses as needed.
   .
   # Constipation: stool seen on OSH CT scan, no BM in several days
   - repeat erythromycin, protonix, reglan as CT scan did not show
   evidence of obstruction
   - ? bowel regimen
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Trached, on vent; patient tachypneic overnight
   with RR 30s.  ABG with primary respiratory alkalosis.
   - continue on volume assist control.
   .
   # CAD: on b-blocker, statin, aspirin at home, not continued at OSH
   - continue to hold pending acute infection
   .
   # Aortic regurgitation:
   - Monitor volume status and hemodynamics
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TPN when has access
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   # Access: PIV x 2
   # Communication: daughter [**Name (NI) 532**] [**Known lastname 12477**] is HCP [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12482**].
   # Code:  Full per HCP daughter
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   16 Gauge - [**2123-5-13**] 08:53 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2123-5-13**] 08:53 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who has undergone multiple surgical interventions and is being transferred to a new hospital with concerns about infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. The patient has a fever, tachypnea, and is intubated. The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, abnormal kidney function, and abnormal blood clotting. The patient has a history of seizures and is being treated for possible infected mesh and hematoma.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachypnea, and abnormal laboratory results suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and the patient is on a ventilator, which increases the risk of respiratory failure and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver damage, which can lead to liver failure if not treated promptly.
4. Renal failure: The patient's abnormal kidney function may indicate kidney damage, which can lead to renal failure if not treated promptly.
5. Infection: The patient's infected mesh and hematoma increase the risk of infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death.
6. Endocarditis: The patient's history of seizures and abnormal liver function may indicate the possibility of endocarditis, which can lead to heart failure and death if not treated promptly.
7. Constipation: The patient's lack of bowel movement and abnormal liver function may indicate constipation, which can lead to bowel obstruction and other complications if not treated promptly.
8. Aortic regurgitation: The patient's history of aortic regurgitation may increase the risk of heart failure and death if not treated promptly.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis, respiratory failure, and organ dysfunction.
2. Treat the patient's infected mesh and hematoma promptly with antibiotics and surgical intervention if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's liver and kidney function closely and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent liver and kidney failure.
4. Continue to provide respiratory support as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
5. Consider performing an EEG and head CT to rule out seizure activity and other neurological complications.
6. Consider performing a TTE to rule out endocarditis and other cardiac complications.
7. Consider performing a CT scan of the abdomen to rule out bowel obstruction and other abdominal complications.
8. Continue to provide prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from the operating room (OSH) with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has a history of multiple surgical interventions. His current condition is as follows:

* Fever: 102°F (39.3°C) with a spike overnight
* Respiratory rate: 35 breaths per minute (bpm) with a primary respiratory alkalosis on ABG
* Intubated and on ventilator support with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute
* Hemodynamic monitoring shows a heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 135/76 mmHg, and a central venous pressure of 12 mmHg
* Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count of 12.8 K/uL, a decreased platelet count of 283 K/uL, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST)
* Imaging studies show a complex post-surgical anatomy with bibasilar atelectasis on chest X-ray and inflammatory changes on CT scan

Potential medical complications:

* Infected mesh or hematoma: The patient's fever, elevated white blood cell count, and laboratory results suggest an abdominal source of infection. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the extent of the infection and to prevent complications such as sepsis or organ failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and primary respiratory alkalosis on ABG indicate respiratory failure. Continued ventilator support and monitoring are necessary to prevent further complications.
* Hepatitis C infection: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may be due to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and to prevent complications such as liver failure.
* Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased sodium level suggest ARF. Fluid boluses and continued monitoring are necessary to prevent further complications.
* Constipation: The patient's stool seen on OSH CT scan and lack of bowel movement in several days indicate constipation. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the cause and to prevent complications such as bowel obstruction.
* Cardiac issues: The patient's history of aortic regurgitation and cardiac arrest at home indicate cardiac issues. Monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent further complications.
* Endocarditis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of endocarditis. Further evaluation and treatment are needed to determine the extent of the infection and to prevent complications such as sepsis or organ failure.

Recommendations:

* Continue to trend the patient's temperature, white blood cell count, and laboratory results to monitor for signs of infection or complications.
* Continue to provide ventilator support and monitor the patient's respiratory status.
* Continue to provide fluid boluses as needed to prevent further complications.
* Consider antibiotics for the patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count.
* Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's constipation.
* Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's cardiac issues.
* Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's endocarditis.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has a history of multiple surgical interventions, including Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on mechanical ventilation. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.8, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 17,000. His liver function tests are elevated, and he has a heterogeneous lesion in the left lobe of the liver. He also has a coarsened echotexture of the liver, compatible with known cirrhosis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection: The patient has a high risk of infection due to his surgical history and the presence of infected mesh and hematoma.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and his respiratory status is unstable.
3. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, and he has a heterogeneous lesion in the left lobe of the liver.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a high risk of renal failure due to his age, surgical history, and the presence of prerenal azotemia.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of aortic regurgitation and is at risk for cardiovascular complications.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of seizures and is at risk for neurological complications due to his respiratory failure and liver disease.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a high risk of gastrointestinal complications due to his surgical history, including the possibility of enterocutaneous fistula.
8. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has a high risk of electrolyte imbalance due to his liver disease, kidney disease, and the use of diuretics.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is at risk for nutritional deficiencies due to his gastrointestinal complications and the need for total parenteral nutrition.

Based on this information, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal status. He also requires treatment for his infections, and his liver and kidney function should be closely monitored.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 74-year-old male who underwent multiple surgical interventions at an outside hospital (OSH) and is now being transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU with multiple comorbidities, including cirrhosis, hypertension, and a history of seizures.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Infection:** The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of infected mesh, infected hematoma, and multiple drain sites. The growth of Gram-negative rods in peritoneal fluid and yeast in bile further supports this concern.
2. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient is already on mechanical ventilation and has primary respiratory alkalosis. His respiratory status may deteriorate further due to the presence of pneumonia, pleural effusion, or other respiratory complications.
3. **Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):** The patient has already developed AKI, which may worsen due to the underlying cirrhosis, hypoperfusion, or other factors.
4. **Seizure Activity:** The patient's head bobbing may be indicative of seizure activity, and the presence of a history of seizures in the past increases the risk of further episodes.
5. **Hepatic Encephalopathy:** The patient's elevated liver function tests (LFTs) and coarsened echotexture of the liver on liver ultrasound may indicate the development of hepatic encephalopathy.
6. **Enterocutaneous Fistula:** The contrast tracking from bowel loops to the anterior abdominal wall on CT abdomen suggests the possibility of an enterocutaneous fistula, which may lead to further complications.
7. **Pulmonary Embolism:** The patient's history of hypertension, cirrhosis, and immobility may increase the risk of developing pulmonary embolism.
8. **Bowel Obstruction:** The patient's constipation and lack of bowel movements for several days may indicate the development of bowel obstruction, which may worsen if not addressed promptly.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies to detect any changes in his condition.
2. Maintain proper infection control measures to prevent the spread of infection.
3. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to assess the patient's bowel function and rule out bowel obstruction.
4. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
5. Consider ordering an EEG to rule out seizure activity.
6. Continue to trend the patient's LFTs and consider ordering a liver biopsy to further evaluate the patient's liver function.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
8. Consider ordering a stress test to evaluate the patient's cardiac function.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a chief complaint of GNR growing from multiple peritoneal fluid cultures. The patient has had an episode of melena today and has been seen by the GI consult, who recommends a percutaneous cholangiogram with surgery. The patient has resp alkalosis and was taken off pressure support for a while overnight with decreased RR. The patient has also been seen by ID consult, who recommends repeat abdominal CT and MRI/duplex of PV, but these tests have not been ordered due to the patient's unstable condition. The patient has received antibiotics, including Vancomycin, Micafungin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 91 bpm, and blood pressure of 151/84 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PPS with a Vt of 500 mL and a FiO2 of 40%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.52, PCO2 of 24 mmHg, and PO2 of 176 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination is notable for an ill-appearing man who is unresponsive with eyes open and head bobbing. The patient has multiple drains in place, including a colostomy, biliary drain, and three JP drains. The patient's lab results show an elevated WBC count, decreased Hct, and elevated Cr and TCO2 levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's GNR growing from multiple peritoneal fluid cultures suggests a high risk of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's resp alkalosis and requirement for CPAP/PPS suggest a high risk of respiratory failure.
3. Wound infection: The patient's wound infection may lead to further complications, including sepsis and organ failure.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's episode of melena today suggests a high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated ALT and AST levels suggest liver dysfunction, which may be exacerbated by the patient's sepsis and respiratory failure.
6. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated Cr and TCO2 levels suggest renal dysfunction, which may be exacerbated by the patient's sepsis and respiratory failure.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's resp alkalosis and requirement for CPAP/PPS suggest a high risk of cardiovascular instability.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with polymicrobial sepsis presumed to be secondary to intraabdominal pathology. The patient has a fever of 100.9°C, and peritoneal fluid cultures are positive. The patient is unable to provide a history due to being unresponsive. The patient has a history of anaphylaxis to iodine and iodine-containing substances.

The patient is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin, micafungin, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient is also receiving heparin sodium for prophylaxis and pantoprazole for gastroprotection.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (100.9°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 148/80 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 13 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is receiving respiratory support with a tracheostomy tube and mechanical ventilation. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.52, PaO2 of 176 mmHg, and PaCO2 of 19 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, overweight/obese
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Unresponsive, no spontaneous movement, no follow-up of simple commands

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 12.8 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 27.6%
* Platelet count: 17 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 95 mg/dL
* Other lab results: See below

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, and further deterioration could lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient has polymicrobial sepsis, which could lead to further organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Wound infection: The patient has a wound infection, which could lead to further complications and increased risk of sepsis.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which could lead to further complications such as seizures and coma.
5. Altered mental status: The patient has altered mental status, which could be due to sepsis, medication, or other underlying conditions.
6. Liver function test abnormalities: The patient has abnormal liver function tests, which could be due to sepsis, medication, or other underlying conditions.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias and muscle weakness.

Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics and monitor for signs of improvement.
2. Optimize respiratory support and monitor for signs of respiratory failure.
3. Monitor for signs of sepsis and organ dysfunction.
4. Monitor for signs of wound infection and consider surgical debridement.
5. Monitor for signs of hypernatremia and consider treatment with IV fluids and diuretics.
6. Monitor for signs of altered mental status and consider treatment with sedatives and neuromuscular blockade.
7. Monitor for signs of liver function test abnormalities and consider treatment with medications and supportive care.
8. Monitor for signs of electrolyte imbalance and consider treatment with IV fluids and diuretics.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with polymicrobial sepsis presumed to be secondary to an intra-abdominal source. The patient is unable to provide a medical history due to being unresponsive.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 100.9°C (38.3°C)
* Heart rate: 83-103 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 148/80 mmHg (97-108 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 13-37 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and heparin. They are also receiving IV fluids, and their fluid balance is being closely monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.8-11.8 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 317 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.7-1.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 95-125 mg/dL
* Other lab results are also included, showing abnormal liver function, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels.

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Well-nourished, overweight/obese
* Cardiovascular: Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: Clear breath sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left lower extremity edema
* Skin: Warm
* Neurological: Unresponsive, no spontaneous movement, tone not assessed

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

* Respiratory failure due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Altered mental status, with etiology not clear
* Wound infection, requiring surgical intervention
* Hypernatremia
* Nutrition issues, with the patient currently receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
* Liver function test (LFT) abnormalities, suggesting obstructive liver disease

The patient requires further imaging, including a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to assess for abscesses or collections, and to optimize drain placement. The patient's hip replacement material and contrast allergy also need to be addressed.

The patient's code status is critically ill, and they require close monitoring and management in the intensive care unit (ICU).

   74 y.o. male s/p multiple surgical interventions at an OSH now being
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concern for infected mesh, infected hematoma,
   and respiratory failure.
   # Fever: Likely abdominal source given Klebsiella, Enterococcus from a
   hematoma at his surgical wound site.  Concern for infected mesh +/-
   hematoma.
   - Trend temp curve, WBC
   - f/u blood cultures, urine culture, sputum culture, biliary cx, 3 JPs
   cx
   - f/u culture data from all drain sites
   - Continue GNB coverage with IV Abx, Vanc and meropenem
   - Micafungin for yeast
   - Surgery team consult (Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **]; f/u any recommendations (will
   discuss cholangigram, feeding)
   - f/u ID consult recs
   - Resite lines (obtain peripherals, pulled PICC)
   .
   # Hypernatremia:
   - On D5W at 100 cc/hr; corrected rapidly to 143 and then discontinued
   D5W.  Repeat 148.  Will restart D5W and monitor closely.
   - continue Q6H Na levels
   .
   # Nutrition: KUB today showing minimal gas throughout the small and
   large bowel.
   - Ordered for TPN but not currently receiving as no dedicated line
   - Optimal would be enteral feeding
 IR may be able to place distal
   feeding tube, likely beyond possible enterocutaneous fistula.
   .
   # Head Bobbing: ? seizure activity.  Started yesterday per daughter. [**Name (NI) **]
   history of seizures in the past, though decreased rhythmic activity
   over night.
   - f/u EEG
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: possibly due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C
   infection
   - continue to trend
   .
   # ARF: Reached peak of 1.9 from baseline of 1.0. Likely prerenal given
   elevated sodium
   - patient received fluid bolus with 1L NS and had creatinine drop to
   1.4 and sodium to 145.  Now stable at 1.6.
   - continue IVF boluses as needed and continue to monitor UOP and renal
   function.
   .
   # Constipation/GIB: stool seen on OSH CT scan, now having melena
   - GI and surgery both aware of new melena.
   - likely no intervention at this time, trend HCT q 8 for now and then
   space to [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Trached, on vent; patient tachypneic overnight
   with RR 30s.  ABG with primary respiratory alkalosis.
   - continue on volume assist control.
   .
   # CAD: on b-blocker, statin, aspirin at home, not continued at OSH
   - continue to hold pending acute infection
   .
   # Aortic regurgitation:
   - Monitor volume status and hemodynamics
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, TPN when has access
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   # Access: PIV x 2
   # Communication: daughter [**Name (NI) 532**] [**Known lastname 12477**] is HCP [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12482**].

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male who has undergone multiple surgical interventions and is now being transferred to a new hospital with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure.

The patient has a significant medical history, including a previous cardiac arrest due to an allergic reaction to IV contrast, and a history of testicular cancer. He has been experiencing fever, tachypnea, and hypernatremia, which are likely related to his abdominal source of infection.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, possibly due to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection. His creatinine levels have peaked at 1.9, likely due to prerenal azotemia, and he has been receiving fluid boluses to manage his renal function.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning, with a history of respiratory failure and a recent episode of tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 30s. His ABG results show primary respiratory alkalosis.

The patient's nutritional status is also concerning, with a recent CT scan showing minimal gas in the small and large bowel, and a history of constipation and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient has multiple drains in place, including a colostomy, biliary drain, and three JP drains, and has a GJ tube in place. He has a history of seizures and is currently experiencing head bobbing, which may be related to seizure activity.

The patient's medication list includes antibiotics, antifungals, and anticoagulants, and he is receiving IV fluids and nutritional support.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Trending temperature, WBC, and blood cultures
* Continuing GNB coverage with IV antibiotics
* Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting antibiotic therapy as necessary
* Managing hypernatremia with D5W and monitoring sodium levels
* Providing nutritional support with TPN and enteral feeding
* Monitoring respiratory status and adjusting ventilator settings as necessary
* Managing constipation and gastrointestinal bleeding with stool softeners and antidiarrheal agents
* Monitoring for signs of seizure activity and adjusting anticonvulsant therapy as necessary

The patient's disposition is ICU pending clinical improvement.

* Heart rate: 79-93 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 150/77-166/95 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16-40 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient has a history of cardiac arrest 13 years ago when he received IV contrast for a CT scan for testicular cancer. He also has a history of dye reaction and has undergone a tube study with contrast with pre-medication without incident.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.7-11.8 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 28.1-28.8%
* Platelet count: 88 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.4-1.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 19-20 mg/dL
* Sodium: 154-148 mmol/L
* Potassium: 3.4-3.5 mmol/L
* Glucose: 113-125 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.5 mmol/L

The patient has undergone several imaging studies, including a CT scan of the abdomen, which showed a liver mass. The patient's AFP level is elevated, and further imaging is needed to evaluate the liver mass.

The patient's clinical status is critical, with concerns for:

* Polymicrobial sepsis
* Respiratory failure
* Altered mental status
* Wound infection
* Hypernatremia
* Nutritional deficiencies
* Liver dysfunction
* Cardiac disease

The patient's plan includes:

* Antibiotic therapy for polymicrobial sepsis
* Further imaging studies to evaluate the liver mass and gut anatomy
* Nutritional support, including TPN and consideration of enteral feeding
* Management of respiratory failure, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy
* Management of altered mental status, including EEG and consideration of nonconvulsive status epilepticus
* Wound care and consideration of surgical debridement
* Hypernatremia management, including fluid boluses and consideration of diuretics
* Monitoring of laboratory results, including liver function tests and electrolyte levels.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital (OSH) with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has a history of cardiac arrest 13 years ago when he received IV contrast for a CT scan.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is trached and on ventilator support with a respiratory alkalosis.
* Cardiovascular: He has a history of cardiac disease, including aortic regurgitation, and is currently receiving prophylactic subcutaneous heparin.
* Neurological: He is unresponsive with eyes open and head bobbing, which may be indicative of seizure activity. An EEG was ordered to further evaluate this.
* Gastrointestinal: He has melena and constipation, and his stool studies are pending.
* Renal: He has acute kidney injury (ARF) with a peak creatinine of 1.9 and is receiving IV fluid boluses as needed.
* Hepatic: He has elevated liver function tests (LFTs) with possible causes including hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection.
* Hematological: He has anemia with a hematocrit (HCT) of 28%.
* Infectious: He has a urinary tract infection (UTI) with E. coli resistant to Zosyn, and his peritoneal fluid is growing E. coli.
* Endocrine: He has hyperglycemia likely due to D5W for management of hypernatremia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory alkalosis may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
* Sepsis: The patient's UTI and peritoneal fluid infection may lead to sepsis.
* Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated LFTs may indicate liver damage, which can lead to hepatic failure.
* Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen, leading to renal failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's melena and constipation may worsen, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Seizure activity: The patient's head bobbing and seizure activity may worsen, leading to seizure-related complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing meropenem and vancomycin for UTI and peritoneal fluid infection.
* Monitoring the patient's temperature, blood cultures, and ID recs.
* Trending the patient's fever curve and f/u blood culture.
* Continuing IVF boluses as needed and monitoring UOP and renal function.
* Trending the patient's LFTs and considering further imaging to further characterize the liver mass.
* Monitoring the patient's electrolyte levels and considering insulin sliding scale for hyperglycemia.
* Continuing prophylactic subcutaneous heparin for DVT and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

The patient's code status is full, and his disposition is pending clinical improvement in the ICU.

   mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   74 y.o. male s/p multiple surgical interventions at an OSH now being
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concern for infected mesh, infected hematoma,
   and respiratory failure.
   # Fever:  Most likely intra-abdominal infection with gram negative rods
   (E. Coli, Klebsiella) growing in peritoneal fluid.  Concern for
   surgical site infection, infected mesh, hematoma.  Patient now afebrile
   for > 24 hours.  Also found to be c. difficile positive.
   - trend fever curve
   - f/u blood culture
   - continue meropenem, vancomycin redose for trough <15
   - continue micafungin for yeast
    - pt underwent line holiday, now with PICC line in place
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u stool studies
   - check CMV VL per ID rec given multiple blood transfusions
   - plan for T tube cholangiogram given elevated LFT; patient will need
   to be pre-medicated with solumedrol/Benadryl d/t previous anaphylactic
   reaction (reportedly VF arrest 13 years ago)
   .
   # Hypernatremia:
   - On D5W at 250 cc/hr; corrected to 145.  Will continue D5W for a
   liter.
   - continue Q6H Na levels
   .
   #Melena:  Patient with 2 episodes of melena overnight, remained
   hemodynamically stable with stable HCT.
   - monitor HCT [**Hospital1 **]
   - transfuse for HCT <25 or active bleeding
   - f/u GI recs
 no plan to scope at this time
   .
   #Liver mass:
   - AFP normal
   - consider further imaging to further characterize, though patient
   cannot have MRI due to L THR that is not compatible with MRI.
   # Nutrition: KUB yesterday showing minimal gas throughout the small and
   large bowel.
   - Ordered for TPN but not currently receiving as no dedicated line
   - Optimal would be enteral feeding
 will need to coordinate with
   either GI or IR to place distal feeding tube beyond EC fistula
   - Nutrition consult for TPN recommendations pending enteral feeding
   tube placement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Trached, on vent; patient with respiratory rate
   20s.  ABG with primary respiratory alkalosis.
   - continue on volume assist control.
   .
   # Head Bobbing: ? seizure activity.  Started on day of admission per
   daughter. [**Name (NI) **] history of seizures in the past, though decreased rhythmic
   activity overnight on HD 1.  No further head bobbing or seizure like
   activity.
   - f/u EEG read
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: possibly due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C
   infection
   - continue to trend
   - T tube cholangiogram to further evaluate
   .
   # ARF: Reached peak of 1.9 from baseline of 1.0. Likely prerenal given
   elevated sodium.  After NS fluid bolus and 2 liters of D5W for
   hypernatremia, creatinine improved to 1.1.
   - continue IVF boluses as needed and continue to monitor UOP and renal
   function.
   .
   # CAD: on b-blocker, statin, aspirin at home, not continued at OSH
   - continue to hold pending acute infection
   .
   # Aortic regurgitation:
   - Monitor volume status and hemodynamics
   .
   Hyperglycemia:  likely due to D5W for management of hypernatremia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .
   # FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes, picc line,  TPN when has access
   # Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin
   # Access: PIV x 2
   # Communication: daughter [**Name (NI) 532**] [**Known lastname 12477**] is HCP [**Telephone/Fax (1) 12482**].
   # Code:  Full per HCP daughter
   # Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   PICC Line - [**2123-5-16**] 02:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has a history of multiple surgical interventions and is currently being treated for a c. difficile infection. He has been febrile for over 24 hours and has a positive blood culture for gram-negative rods. He is also positive for C. difficile and has been started on metronidazole.

The patient has several medical conditions, including hypernatremia, melena, liver mass, and respiratory failure. He is currently being treated with D5W for hypernatremia and is receiving IVF boluses as needed. He has also been started on TPN, but is not currently receiving it due to lack of a dedicated line.

The patient has a history of seizures and is currently being monitored for seizure activity. He has also had a recent episode of head bobbing, which was thought to be possible seizure activity.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated LFTs, possibly due to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection. His creatinine has improved from a peak of 1.9 to 1.1 after receiving IVF boluses and D5W for hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his c. difficile infection and his history of surgical interventions.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently being treated for respiratory failure and is at risk for further deterioration.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia is being managed with D5W, but he is at risk for further electrolyte imbalances.
4. Liver damage: The patient's liver mass and elevated LFTs may indicate liver damage, which could lead to further complications.
5. Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizures and recent episode of head bobbing may indicate seizure activity, which could lead to further complications.
6. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine has improved, but he is at risk for further renal failure due to his underlying medical conditions.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of aortic regurgitation and CAD may increase his risk for cardiovascular complications.
8. GI bleeding: The patient's melena may indicate GI bleeding, which could lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's infection and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure and hypernatremia.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider further imaging to characterize the liver mass.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Consider further GI evaluation to determine the cause of the melena.
8. Consider further imaging to determine the extent of the liver mass and potential liver damage.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male who has undergone multiple surgical interventions and is now being transferred to a new hospital with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is complex and requires careful management.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not treated promptly and aggressively.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is in the 20s, and his ABG shows primary respiratory alkalosis, which may indicate respiratory failure. This can lead to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is elevated, which can lead to dehydration, seizures, and even death if not treated promptly.
4. Melena: The patient's two episodes of melena overnight suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death if not treated promptly.
5. Liver mass: The patient's elevated LFTs and liver mass suggest the possibility of liver disease, which can lead to liver failure, cirrhosis, and even death.
6. ARF: The patient's elevated creatinine level suggests the possibility of acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease, dialysis dependence, and even death.
7. Aortic regurgitation: The patient's aortic regurgitation can lead to heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and even death if not treated promptly.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's elevated glucose level suggests the possibility of hyperglycemia, which can lead to ketoacidosis, hyperosmolar nonketotic coma, and even death if not treated promptly.

To prevent or manage these potential complications, the patient requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment. This includes:

1. Intravenous antibiotics to treat sepsis and prevent further infection.
2. Mechanical ventilation to support the patient's respiratory function and prevent respiratory failure.
3. Fluid management to prevent dehydration and hypernatremia.
4. Blood transfusions to support the patient's hemoglobin and prevent anemia.
5. Medications to manage the patient's liver disease and prevent liver failure.
6. Cardiovascular medications to manage the patient's aortic regurgitation and prevent heart failure.
7. Insulin therapy to manage the patient's hyperglycemia and prevent ketoacidosis.
8. Nutritional support to prevent malnutrition and support the patient's recovery.

In summary, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and aggressive treatment to prevent or manage potential complications.

   74 y.o. male s/p multiple surgical interventions at an OSH now being
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concern for infected mesh, infected hematoma,
   and respiratory failure.
   # Fever:  Most likely intra-abdominal infection with gram negative rods
   (E. Coli, Klebsiella) growing in peritoneal fluid.  Concern for
   surgical site infection, infected mesh, hematoma.  Patient now afebrile
   for > 24 hours.  Also found to be c. difficile positive.
   - trend fever curve
   - f/u blood culture
   - continue meropenem, vancomycin redose for trough <15
   - continue micafungin for yeast
    - pt underwent line holiday, now with PICC line in place
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u stool studies
   - check CMV VL per ID rec given multiple blood transfusions
   - plan for T tube cholangiogram given elevated LFT; patient will need
   to be pre-medicated with solumedrol/Benadryl d/t previous anaphylactic
   reaction (reportedly VF arrest 13 years ago)
   .
   # Hypernatremia:
   - On D5W at 250 cc/hr; corrected to 145.  Will continue D5W for a
   liter.
   - continue Q6H Na levels
   .
   #Melena:  Patient with 2 episodes of melena overnight, remained
   hemodynamically stable with stable HCT.
   - monitor HCT [**Hospital1 **]
   - transfuse for HCT <25 or active bleeding
   - f/u GI recs
 no plan to scope at this time
   .

   - AFP normal
   - consider further imaging to further characterize, though patient
   cannot have MRI due to L THR that is not compatible with MRI.
   # Nutrition: KUB yesterday showing minimal gas throughout the small and
   large bowel.
   - Ordered for TPN but not currently receiving as no dedicated line
   - Optimal would be enteral feeding
 will need to coordinate with
   either GI or IR to place distal feeding tube beyond EC fistula
   - Nutrition consult for TPN recommendations pending enteral feeding
   tube placement.
   .

   20s.  ABG with primary respiratory alkalosis.
   - continue on volume assist control.

   daughter. [**Name (NI) **] history of seizures in the past, though decreased rhythmic
   activity overnight on HD 1.  No further head bobbing or seizure like
   activity.
   - f/u EEG read
   .
   # Elevated LFTs: possibly due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C
   infection
   - continue to trend
   - T tube cholangiogram to further evaluate
   .
   # ARF: Reached peak of 1.9 from baseline of 1.0. Likely prerenal given
   elevated sodium.  After NS fluid bolus and 2 liters of D5W for
   hypernatremia, creatinine improved to 1.1.
   - continue IVF boluses as needed and continue to monitor UOP and renal
   function.
   .
   # CAD: on b-blocker, statin, aspirin at home, not continued at OSH
   - continue to hold pending acute infection
   .
   # Aortic regurgitation:
   - Monitor volume status and hemodynamics
   .
   Hyperglycemia:  likely due to D5W for management of hypernatremia
   - insulin sliding scale
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with concerns for infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has undergone multiple surgical interventions and is now being transferred to a new hospital. The patient is currently afebrile, but has a history of c. difficile infection and has grown gram-negative rods in peritoneal fluid. He has a PICC line in place and is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem. The patient has hypernatremia, which is being managed with D5W, and is also experiencing melena, likely due to bleeding from the surgical site. He has elevated liver enzymes and is being considered for further imaging to characterize the liver mass. The patient is receiving respiratory support with a tracheostomy tube and is being monitored for signs of respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient has a history of c. difficile infection and is at risk for further infection, particularly with gram-negative rods.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and fever suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could worsen his condition.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is in the 20s, and he has primary respiratory alkalosis on his ABG, which may indicate respiratory failure.
4. Hemorrhage: The patient's melena and history of bleeding from the surgical site suggest the possibility of further hemorrhage.
5. Liver failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and liver mass may indicate liver failure, which could worsen his condition.
6. Kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine and decreased urine output suggest the possibility of kidney injury.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of hyperglycemia and use of D5W may increase his risk of hypoglycemia.
8. Anaphylaxis: The patient has a history of anaphylaxis and is at risk for further reactions to medications or other substances.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory values closely to detect any changes in his condition.
2. Consider further imaging to characterize the liver mass and to rule out other causes of elevated liver enzymes.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with D5W and monitor his sodium levels closely.
4. Consider transferring the patient to a higher-level care facility if his condition worsens or if he requires more advanced treatment.
5. Consult with the patient's primary care physician and other specialists to develop a comprehensive treatment plan.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider adjusting his ventilator settings or considering other forms of respiratory support if necessary.
7. Consider ordering additional tests, such as an EEG, to rule out seizure activity.
8. Continue to manage the patient's pain and discomfort with appropriate medications and other interventions.

The patient has a complex medical history, including a history of seizures, hepatitis C infection, and aortic regurgitation. He is currently receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Fever: The patient's fever has been trending downward, and he is currently afebrile. However, the possibility of an intra-abdominal infection with gram-negative rods cannot be ruled out.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels have been corrected, and he is currently receiving D5W to manage his hypernatremia.
* Melena: The patient has had two episodes of melena overnight, which may be related to his gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with a respiratory rate of 20s and primary respiratory alkalosis.
* Head bobbing: The patient has had episodes of head bobbing, which may be related to seizure activity.
* Elevated LFTs: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, which may be related to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection.
* ARF: The patient has developed acute renal failure, which is likely prerenal given his elevated sodium levels.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated LFTs suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's melena and elevated LFTs suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and organ failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen, leading to respiratory acidosis and cardiac arrest.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure could worsen, leading to electrolyte imbalances and organ failure.
* Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizures and current episodes of head bobbing suggest the possibility of seizure activity, which could lead to respiratory and cardiac arrest.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, it is recommended that he receive close monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old man who has been admitted to the ICU with a complicated medical history, including a laceration of the gastric artery, recurrent bowel infections, and a liver lesion suspicious for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The patient has had multiple surgeries, including ERCP, and has been treated with various antibiotics and antifungals.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on a tracheostomy collar and is receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP). His arterial blood gas (ABG) results show a pH of 7.18, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 18 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 95 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 140/81 mmHg, and his heart rate is 76 beats per minute (bpm). His cardiac rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Abdominal: The patient has a liver lesion suspicious for HCC, and has had recurrent bowel infections. He has also had melena (black tarry stools) for 3 days.
* Neurological: The patient is awake and follows simple commands, but his neurological examination is otherwise unremarkable.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin (Hb) of 8.5 g/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC) of 11.8 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count (Plt) of 276 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL
* Glucose of 115 mg/dL
* Liver function tests (LFTs) show elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels
* Amylase and lipase levels are normal
* Albumin level is 2.2 g/dL
* Lactic acid level is 1.9 mmol/L
* Calcium, magnesium, and phosphorus levels are within normal range

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further interventions such as mechanical ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Intraabdominal infection: The patient's recurrent bowel infections and melena suggest an ongoing intraabdominal infection, which may require further antibiotic treatment and consideration of surgical intervention.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver lesion suspicious for HCC and elevated LFTs suggest a risk of liver failure, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Bleeding complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and melena suggest a risk of further bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of anticoagulation therapy.
* Seizures: The patient's head bobbing and altered mental status suggest a risk of seizures, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Malnutrition: The patient's recent history of bowel infections and melena may have led to malnutrition, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

In summary, the patient is a critically ill individual with a complex medical history and multiple ongoing medical complications. He requires close monitoring and further evaluation to address his respiratory, abdominal, liver, and neurological issues.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who has undergone multiple surgical interventions and is now being transferred to a new hospital with concerns about infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has a history of seizures, hypertension, and aortic regurgitation. His current condition includes:

* Fever: Resolved, but concern for intra-abdominal infection with gram-negative rods
* Respiratory failure: Trached, with primary respiratory alkalosis
* Hypernatremia: Resolved, but will continue to monitor
* Melena: Patient has had two episodes of melena overnight, but remains hemodynamically stable
* Liver mass: Consider further imaging to characterize, but patient cannot have MRI due to incompatible L THR
* Nutrition: Patient is receiving TPN, but optimal would be enteral feeding
* CMV+: Patient is CMV positive, and ID recs are being followed
* Head bobbing: Possible seizure activity, but no further episodes
* Elevated LFTs: Possibly due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C infection
* ARF: Patient has reached peak creatinine of 1.9, likely prerenal given elevated sodium
* Hyperglycemia: Patient is receiving insulin sliding scale

Potential medical complications:

1. Intra-abdominal infection: Patient's fever has resolved, but there is still concern for intra-abdominal infection with gram-negative rods. Further monitoring and treatment are needed.
2. Respiratory failure: Patient's respiratory rate is in the 20s, and he has primary respiratory alkalosis. He is being treated with volume assist control and tolerating trach collar.
3. Melena: Patient has had two episodes of melena overnight, and further monitoring is needed to ensure hemodynamic stability.
4. Liver mass: Patient has a liver mass, and further imaging is needed to characterize it. However, patient cannot have MRI due to incompatible L THR.
5. CMV+: Patient is CMV positive, and ID recs are being followed. Further monitoring and treatment are needed.
6. Head bobbing: Patient had possible seizure activity, but no further episodes. Further monitoring is needed to rule out seizure activity.
7. Elevated LFTs: Patient's LFTs are elevated, and further monitoring is needed to determine if it is due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C infection.
8. ARF: Patient has reached peak creatinine of 1.9, and further monitoring is needed to determine if it is prerenal or postrenal.
9. Hyperglycemia: Patient is receiving insulin sliding scale, and further monitoring is needed to ensure glycemic control.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor patient's fever curve and treat any further episodes of fever.
2. Continue to treat patient's respiratory failure with volume assist control and monitor for any changes in respiratory rate or oxygen saturation.
3. Continue to monitor patient's melena and ensure hemodynamic stability.
4. Continue to follow up on patient's liver mass with further imaging and treatment as needed.
5. Continue to monitor patient's CMV+ status and follow up on ID recs.
6. Continue to monitor patient's head bobbing and rule out seizure activity.
7. Continue to monitor patient's elevated LFTs and determine if it is due to hypoperfusion vs. hepatitis C infection.
8. Continue to monitor patient's ARF and determine if it is prerenal or postrenal.
9. Continue to monitor patient's hyperglycemia and ensure glycemic control with insulin sliding scale.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU with concerns about infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with a C. difficile infection and has undergone multiple surgical interventions.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 147/75 mmHg. He is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy in place.

The patient has a history of seizures and has been experiencing head bobbing, which may be related to seizure activity. An EEG read is pending.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, likely due to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection. He has also developed hypernatremia, which has been corrected with D5W. His creatinine level has improved after IVF boluses and D5W.

The patient's nutritional status is a concern, with a history of malnutrition and a recent episode of melena. He is receiving TPN without lipids, but optimal enteral feeding would be preferred.

The patient's medication list includes antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals, as well as medications for hyperglycemia and hypernatremia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of infected mesh and hematoma, and is at risk for developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy in place, which may increase the risk of respiratory complications.
3. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of seizures and has been experiencing head bobbing, which may be related to seizure activity. Further neurological complications may arise if the patient's seizures are not well-controlled.
4. Hepatic complications: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, which may indicate liver damage or dysfunction. Further complications may arise if the patient's liver function does not improve.
5. Renal complications: The patient has developed acute kidney injury, which may increase the risk of further renal complications if not managed properly.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of malnutrition and has experienced melena, which may increase the risk of further gastrointestinal complications if not managed properly.
7. Infection: The patient has a C. difficile infection and may be at risk for developing further infections if not managed properly.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old neonate admitted to the ICU with suspected gastrointestinal bleeding and sepsis. The patient has a history of abdominal fluid cultures showing yeast (C. albicans) and has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, micafungin, and metronidazole. The patient has a G-tube and duodenostomy with a small bowel follow-through study planned to confirm the position of the T-tube and rule out leaks or obstruction.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, and blood pressure of 147/75 mmHg. The patient has a SpO2 of 100% and is receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheal mask.

The patient has a history of hypernatremia, which has improved to 142 mmol/L. The patient's lab results show an elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes. The patient's albumin level is low, and their lactate acid level is elevated.

The patient has a G-tube and duodenostomy, and a small bowel follow-through study is planned to confirm the position of the T-tube and rule out leaks or obstruction. The patient's respiratory support includes oxygen therapy through a tracheal mask.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's history of sepsis and continued use of antibiotics, including vancomycin and metronidazole, may lead to sepsis-related complications, such as multi-organ failure.
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and continued use of anticoagulant therapy may lead to further bleeding complications.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's history of hypernatremia may lead to complications, such as seizures, if not properly managed.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old man who underwent ERCP and suffered a gastric artery laceration, leading to respiratory failure and abdominal infection. He has a duodenostomy tube with a leak, and barium studies from yesterday showed that the barium is not passing through his stomach. The patient is currently receiving TPN due to his inability to tolerate oral nutrition. He is also receiving antibiotics, including Piperacillin/Tazobactam, Micafungin, Vancomycin, Meropenem, and Metronidazole. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/68 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of infection, with elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate dehydrogenase levels. His liver function tests are also abnormal, with elevated alanine transaminase and aspartate transaminase levels. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but his albumin level is low.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to his inability to clear secretions and his increased risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Abdominal sepsis: The patient's abdominal infection may spread to other parts of his body, leading to septic shock and organ failure.
3. Duodenal leak: The patient's duodenostomy tube leak may lead to peritonitis and further complications.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's inability to tolerate oral nutrition may lead to malnutrition and further compromise his immune system.
5. CMV infection: The patient's CMV viral load is elevated, which may lead to CMV disease and further complications.
6. Seizures: The patient's elevated lactate dehydrogenase level may indicate an increased risk of seizures, which may be exacerbated by his underlying medical conditions.
7. DVT and pulmonary embolism: The patient's immobility and underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing DVT and pulmonary embolism.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's abdominal infection and underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding.
9. VAP: The patient's respiratory failure and underlying medical conditions may increase his risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia.

   74 y.o. male s/p multiple surgical interventions at an OSH now being
   transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] with concern for infected mesh, infected hematoma,

   (E. Coli, Klebsiella) growing in peritoneal fluid.  Concern for
   surgical site infection, infected mesh, hematoma.  Patient now afebrile
   since [**2123-5-15**] at noon.  Also found to be c. difficile positive.

   rate 20s.  ABG with primary respiratory alkalosis. Has been
   transitioned to trach collar and doing well for several days.

   .

   - monitor HCT [**Hospital1 **]

 no plan to scope at this time

   - consider further imaging to further characterize, though patient
   cannot have MRI due to L THR that is not compatible with MRI.
   .

   bowel, duodenostomy study with contrast that did not progress beyond
   the duodenum.  Drains in place still draining white contrast.
   - started on TPN

   - Surgery recommending tube feeds via duodenostomy tube; will clarify
   with surgery as contrast has not progressed.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who underwent multiple surgical interventions at an outside hospital (OSH) for infected mesh and hematoma. He was transferred to the current hospital with concerns about infected mesh, hematoma, and respiratory failure. He is currently in the ICU with a tracheostomy, receiving mechanical ventilation, and has a percutaneous duodenostomy tube (PG tube) and a gastrojejunostomy tube (GJ tube) in place.

The patient has a history of c. difficile positivity and is being treated with metronidazole and vancomycin. He also has a positive CMV test and is being treated with micafungin.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Fever: The patient's fever has resolved since May 15, but there is concern about surgical site infection, infected mesh, and hematoma.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is tracheostomized and has been weaned off mechanical ventilation. He is being monitored closely for respiratory status.
* Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are slowly increasing and are being managed with D5W.
* Melena: The patient has had two episodes of melena overnight, but his hemodynamic status is stable.
* Liver mass: The patient has a liver mass, but further imaging is needed to characterize it.
* Nutrition: The patient is receiving TPN and has a duodenostomy tube in place, which is draining white contrast material.
* CMV+: The patient is positive for CMV and is being treated with micafungin.
* Head bobbing: The patient has a history of seizures and has been experiencing head bobbing, which may be related to seizure activity.

Potential medical complications:

* Sepsis: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of sepsis.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored, and there is a risk of further respiratory decline.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver mass and elevated liver enzymes suggest the possibility of liver failure.
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's melena and elevated liver enzymes suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia is being managed with insulin, but there is a risk of further hyperglycemia.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia suggest the possibility of electrolyte imbalance.
* Infection: The patient's positive blood cultures and c. difficile positivity suggest the possibility of infection.
* Seizure activity: The patient's history of seizures and head bobbing suggest the possibility of seizure activity.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with D5W.
* Continue to monitor the patient's liver enzymes and consider further imaging to characterize the liver mass.
* Continue to manage the patient's c. difficile positivity with metronidazole and vancomycin.
* Consider further imaging to rule out gastrointestinal bleeding.
* Continue to monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust insulin as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust IV fluids as needed.
* Consider further imaging to rule out infection.
* Consider consulting with neurology to further evaluate the patient's seizure activity.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

**Medical History:**

The patient is a 74-year-old male who has undergone multiple surgical interventions at an outside hospital (OSH) for infected mesh and hematoma, and is now being transferred to the ICU at [**Hospital1 5**] with concerns for infected mesh, hematoma, and respiratory failure. The patient has a history of seizures, hepatitis C infection, and aortic regurgitation.

**Current Condition:**

The patient is currently being managed for:

1. **Fever**: The patient's fever has resolved since May 15th, but the cause is still suspected to be an intra-abdominal infection with gram-negative rods.
2. **Respiratory Failure**: The patient is trached and was previously on ventilator support. He is now on a trach collar and is doing well.
3. **Hypernatremia**: The patient's sodium levels are slowly increasing, and he is being treated with D5W to manage this condition.
4. **Melena**: The patient has had two episodes of melena overnight, but his hemodynamic status is stable.
5. **Liver Mass**: The patient has a liver mass, but further imaging is needed to characterize it.
6. **Nutrition**: The patient is currently receiving TPN, but enteral feeding is optimal. A duodenostomy study showed minimal gas in the small and large bowel.
7. **CMV**: The patient has tested positive for CMV, and further ID recs are needed regarding suppressive therapy.
8. **Head Bobbing**: The patient's head bobbing activity has decreased overnight, but further EEG read is needed.
9. **Elevated LFTs**: The patient's liver function tests are elevated, possibly due to hypoperfusion or hepatitis C infection.
10. **ARF**: The patient has acute renal failure, which is likely prerenal given his elevated sodium levels.
11. **Hyperglycemia**: The patient's blood glucose levels are high, likely due to D5W for management of hypernatremia.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

Based on the patient's current condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. **Surgical site infection**: The patient's infected mesh and hematoma may lead to further surgical site infections.
2. **Respiratory failure**: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if not closely monitored.
3. **Renal failure**: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not managed properly.
4. **Infection**: The patient's positive CMV and elevated LFTs may indicate a systemic infection.
5. **Seizure activity**: The patient's history of seizures and head bobbing activity may indicate a risk for seizure activity.
6. **Hepatitis C infection**: The patient's history of hepatitis C infection may lead to further liver damage.
7. **Aortic regurgitation**: The patient's aortic regurgitation may lead to further cardiovascular complications.

**Plan:**

Based on the patient's current condition, the plan is to:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Manage the patient's hypernatremia with D5W and electrolyte repletion.
3. Continue IVF boluses as needed and monitor UOP and renal function.
4. Manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin sliding scale.
5. Continue TPN and consider enteral feeding.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests and consider further imaging for the liver mass.
7. Manage the patient's CMV infection with ID recs.
8. Monitor the patient's seizure activity and consider further EEG read.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider further management for ARF.
10. Monitor the patient's aortic regurgitation and manage volume status and hemodynamics accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old male who underwent multiple surgical interventions at an outside hospital (OSH) for concerns of infected mesh, infected hematoma, and respiratory failure. He was transferred to our hospital with a diagnosis of respiratory failure, hypernatremia, melena, liver mass, CMV positivity, and ARF. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, TPN, and various medications for his conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Intra-abdominal infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest an ongoing intra-abdominal infection, which may require further surgical intervention.
2. Surgical site infection: The patient's surgical site may be infected, which could lead to further complications and require additional surgical interventions.
3. Infected mesh: The patient's infected mesh may require removal or revision surgery to prevent further complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as pneumonia or respiratory arrest.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may require further management with IV fluids and electrolyte supplementation to prevent further complications.
6. Melena: The patient's melena may be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to further complications such as anemia or hemorrhagic shock.
7. Liver mass: The patient's liver mass may be benign or malignant, and further imaging or biopsy may be necessary to determine the cause.
8. CMV positivity: The patient's CMV positivity may require further management with antiviral therapy to prevent further complications.
9. ARF: The patient's ARF may require further management with IV fluids and electrolyte supplementation to prevent further complications.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's aortic regurgitation and CAD may require further management with medication and lifestyle changes to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV antibiotics and antiviral therapy as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Manage the patient's hypernatremia with IV fluids and electrolyte supplementation.
4. Monitor the patient's melena and consider further gastrointestinal evaluation if necessary.
5. Consider further imaging or biopsy to determine the cause of the liver mass.
6. Continue antiviral therapy for CMV positivity.
7. Monitor the patient's ARF and adjust IV fluids and electrolyte supplementation as necessary.
8. Manage the patient's cardiovascular conditions with medication and lifestyle changes.
9. Consider further evaluation of the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms to determine the cause of his melena.
10. Monitor the patient's overall condition closely and adjust treatment plans as necessary to prevent further complications.
